newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexican corn farmers win 120 mln peso credit line.
newsitem.headline: Mexican corn farmers win 120 mln peso credit line.

text.p: A Mexican retail bank and the rural credit institution have opened a credit line to 5,000 corn farmers in western and central Mexico for 120 million pesos, trading company Comagro said Tuesday.

The scheme of mixed capital from Banco International, the banking arm of Grupo Financiero Bital, and Fira, a state lending institution focused on agriculture, is a shot in the arm for cash-strapped corn farmers.
"In 1996, they gave us a credit line for 18 million pesos," Comagra manager Rodolfo Lopez Macias told Reuters, emphasising the huge increase in credits available.
Comagra groups around 40,000 growers in 25 associations in the states of Jalisco, Nayarit, Colima, Michoacan, Guanajuato, Aguascalientes and Zacatecas -- Mexico's central grain belt.

The company has become one of the main trading links between farmers and grains users, whose linking of the two have opened up credit lines and other financing mechanisms as well as contract production and technological developments.
Lopez Macias said 120 million pesos will benefit the planting of more than 25,000 hectares of white corn, estimating an average yield of 6.5 tonnes per hectare.
